thread.title: Richard Petty: The history of The King in the Daytona 500
thread.title_full: Richard Petty: The history of The King in the Daytona 500

title: Richard Petty: The history of The King in the Daytona 500
text:
Feb 6, 2017 at 4:44p ET 0Shares 
Richard Petty appeared in 32 Daytona 500s and won a record seven times. The King saw a ton of success throughout his career in the Great American Race but definitely had his fair share of struggles in the sport’s biggest race. 
Take a look at every single appearance The King made in the Daytona 500: RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1959 
The King didn’t have much success in his first Daytona 500. His engine gave out after eight laps and he finished 57 th . His father, Lee Petty, won the race, though. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1960 
The second try for Petty went much better. He finished third in the race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1961 
Petty didn’t compete in the 500 in 1961 because he tangled with Junior Johnson in the qualifying race, destroying his car. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1962 
After missing the race in 1961 because of his qualifying accident, Petty finished second to Fireball Roberts in 1962. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1963 
It was obvious that Petty was close to breaking through in 1963. He finished sixth. Tiny Lund won the race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1964 
In 1964, Petty broke through for his first Daytona 500 win. Nobody could have imagined he’d go on to win a record seven at the time. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1966 
After missing the 1965 Daytona 500, Petty went right back to Victory Lane, becoming the first driver to win a second Daytona 500. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1967 
Petty had engine troubles late but still pulled off an eighth-place finish. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1968 
A top-10 finish became an expectation for Petty at the 500. He finished eighth again in 1968. 1969 
For the third year in a row, Petty finished eighth place in the Great American Race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1970 
Engine problems ended Petty’s run of top-10 finishes at Daytona. He only completed eight laps and finished 39 th . RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1971 
After losing an engine in 1970, The King rebounded with his third victory in the following season. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1972 
A valve cost Petty a chance for his fourth Daytona 500 win in ’72. He retired from the race after 80 laps and finished 26 th . RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1973 
The King won his fourth 500 in ’73 beating Bobby Isaac by two laps. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1974 
Petty became the first back-to-back winner in the history of the Daytona 500 when he won in 1974. He also won his unprecedented fifth Daytona 500. Nobody else has won more than four 500s. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1975 
The three-peat fell short in 1975 as Petty finished seventh-place, eight laps behind race winner, Benny Parsons. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1976 
In one of the most historic finishes in the history of the 500, Pearson and Petty collided in the final turn. Pearson got his car re-fired and limped across the line for the win while Petty’s car sat inches short of the finish line, where his crew came and pushed him across. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1977 
Engine trouble took Petty out early in 1977. He finished 26 th . 1978 
An accident in ’78 ended Petty’s day after 60 laps. He finished 33 rd . Bob Harmeyer Getty Images 1979 
In the race that put NASCAR on the map, Petty won his historic sixth 500 as Cale Yarborough and the Allison brothers fought in the infield grass. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1980 
An issue with the clutch put the No. 43 car out after 157 laps. Petty finished 25 th . Robert Alexander Getty Images 1981 
17 years after his first Daytona 500 victory, Petty won his seventh and final Great American Race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1982 
An accident put Petty out at the halfway point with a 27 th -place finish. 1983 
If Petty wasn’t winning the race, it was usually an engine that put him out of the 500. He finished 38 th after losing an engine in ’83. 1984 
A mechanical failure knocked Petty out in 1984. It was a camshaft that led to the 31 st -place result. Focus on Sport Getty Images 1985 
It was the clutch again that led to Petty finished 34 th in ’85. Focus on Sport Getty Images 1986 
An accident continued a long stretch of struggles after so much success at Daytona. Petty finished 36 th . Robert Alexander Getty Images 1987 
For the last time in his career, Petty would post a top-five in the Daytona 500. He finished third in ’87. Focus on Sport Getty Images 1988 
One of the more severe crashes in Petty's career came on Lap 104 and ended another day early for The King. He finished 34 th . RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 1989 
In ’89, Petty finished two laps down in 17 th position. Focus on Sport Getty Images 1990 
Over 30 years since his first Daytona 500, Petty didn’t have a great day, finishing 17 laps down in 34 th . Focus on Sport Getty Images 1991 
Petty started third in 1991 but ended up five laps down with a 19 th -place finish when the race ended. Focus on Sport Getty Images 1992 
In his final Daytona 500 appearance, Petty finished two laps down in 16 th -place after starting the race in 32 nd . Focus on Sport Getty Images
